funder.name: Ontario Ministry of Research and Innovation

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Approximately 1460 species of spiders have been reported from Canada, 3% of the global fauna. This study provides a <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcode reference library for 1018 of these species based upon the analysis of more than 30 000 specimens. The sequence results show a clear barcode gap in most cases with a mean intraspecific divergence of 0.78% vs. a minimum nearest‐neighbour (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">NN</jats:styled-content>) distance averaging 7.85%. The sequences were assigned to 1359 Barcode index numbers (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s) with 1344 of these <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s composed of specimens belonging to a single currently recognized species. There was a perfect correspondence between <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content> membership and a known species in 795 cases, while another 197 species were assigned to two or more <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s (556 in total). A few other species (26) were involved in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content> merges or in a combination of merges and splits. There was only a weak relationship between the number of specimens analysed for a species and its <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content> count. However, three species were clear outliers with their specimens being placed in 11–22 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s. Although all <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content> splits need further study to clarify the taxonomic status of the entities involved, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcodes discriminated 98% of the 1018 species. The present survey conservatively revealed 16 species new to science, 52 species new to Canada and major range extensions for 426 species. However, if most <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content> splits detected in this study reflect cryptic taxa, the true species count for Canadian spiders could be 30–50% higher than currently recognized.</jats:p>
title: Untangling taxonomy: a <scp>DNA</scp> barcode reference library for <scp>C</scp>anadian spiders
